Study: Modeling the impact of mass influenza vaccination and public health interventions on COVID-19 epidemics with limited detection capability
Factors: contact rate
Excerpt: If ùëüùëê increases by 5 times, the cumulative number of confirmed cases will decrease by 93.6%
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; Timeline: January 23rd to March 29th 2020

Study: A model for COVID-19 with isolation, quarantine and testing as control measures
Factors: isolation (social distancing)
Excerpt: The mild lockdown of A2 reduces more than half of the infections w.r.t. the no action situation A1, while the strict lockdowns A3 and A4 induce a reduction of the order of 10‚àí2 in total recovered, deaths and positive tests. In this particular scenario, people that are not in isolation have nearly 6 times more chance to be infected.
Measure of Evidence: Timeline: February 15th - May 6th

Study: Social Distancing is Effective at Mitigating COVID-19 Transmission in the United States
Factors: social distancing (number of individual trips made in each county, each day)
Excerpt: Our analysis reveals that social distancing is strongly correlated with decreased COVID-19 case growth rates for the 25 most affected counties in the United States, with a lag period consistent with the incubation time of SARS-CoV-2. We also demonstrate evidence that social distancing was already under way in many U.S. counties before county and state-level policies were implemented. This study strongly supports social distancing as an effective way to mitigate COVID-19 transmission in the United States.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: United States; Timeline: January 1 through April 20, 2020

Study: Impacts of social and economic factors on the transmission of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China
Factors: social distancing in local communities
Excerpt: After controlling for time-invariant city fixed effects and time effects that are common to all cities, on average, one new infection leads to 1.142 more cases in the next week, but 0.824 fewer cases 1 week later. The negative effect can be attributed to the fact that both local authorities and residents would have taken more protective measures in response to a higher perceived risk of contracting the virus given more time.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; Timeline: January 19 - February 29, 2020

Study: A multi-region discrete time mathematical modeling of the dynamics of Covid-19 virus propagation using optimal control
Factors: implementation of healthy protocol programs and awareness campaigns
Excerpt: Figure 6 shows that the number of the exposed individuals in region1 decreased from 868.52 (without controls) to 804.34 (with controls) at the end of the implementation of the proposed strategy. Figure 7 demonstrates that the number of the infected individuals in region 1 decreases from 657.01 (without controls) to 608.64 (with controls) at the end of the implementation of the proposed strategy.

Study: Evaluation of effects of public health interventions on COVID-19 transmission for Pakistan: A mathematical simulation study
Factors: flexible social distancing
Excerpt: With flexible social distancing (Scenario 4), the estimated total number of cumulative case fatalities is higher estimated at 3,995.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Pakistan; Timeline: beginning on April 5th, 2020 run for one calendar year

Study: A stochastic epidemic model of COVID-19 disease
Factors: influence of number of contacts
Excerpt: We consider the dependence on the number of contacts on the evolution of the disease when N = 10, 5, 4 and 3. Let us point out that when N = 5 in one of the 30 simulations the epidemic did not go forward when N = 4 it happened in two cases. On the other hand, when N = 3 and with our initial conditions, only in 1 of the 30 simulations the disease went on.
Measure of Evidence: Closed population of 10000 inhabitants; Timeline: 180 days

Study: COVID-19 Control Strategies and Intervention Effects in Resource Limited Settings: A Modeling Study
Factors: physical distancing defined as avoiding large gatherings, no handshake, minimizing physical proximity)
Excerpt: Year-long physical distancing measures will reduce peak demand to 36% (IQR 23%-46%) and annual morality to 67% (IQR 48%-77%) of base scenario.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Nepal; City: Kathmandu; Timeline: beginning on March 24

Study: Investigating duration and intensity of Covid-19 social-distancing strategies
Factors: contact reduction policies
Excerpt: Social contact reduction and associated reduction in R push new 160 infections further into the future. Hence, the more intense the social distancing measures in terms of contact reduction, the longer the duration needs to be to have an 162 added value; i.e. a relatively lower fatality rate. In other words, the harder you break, the longer it takes. For instance, 40% contact reduction needs to be applied for additional 600 days to 165 outperform a 30% contact reduction in scenario 2 (see Fig. 6). The lower the basic reproduction in the scenarios, the larger the time lag associated with an intensification of social distancing (see Fig. 6, scenarios 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6).

Study: Strong correlations between power-law growth of COVID-19 in four continents and the inefficiency of soft quarantine strategies
Factors: large social distance
Excerpt: The light blue curves, related to large social distance (Œ∏=0.8), are the most efficient scenarios to induce an accentuated reduction of the growth and a fast convergence to the maximal number of confirmed cases.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Italy, France; Timeline: beginning on March 28th

Study: Modelling the potential impact of social distancing on the COVID-19 epidemic in South Africa
Factors: social distancing i.e. keeping space between yourself and other people outside your home
Excerpt: Reducing the level of social distancing from 55% to 53% (œÅ = 0.47) would increase the number of cumulative cases by about 23% at the end of lock-down on 30 April 2020; Increasing the level of social distancing from 55% to 57% (œÅ = 0.43), 59% (œÅ = 0.41) and 61% (œÅ = 0.39) would avert the cumulative cases by about 18%, 32% and 53% respectively at the end of lockdown on 30 April 2020
Measure of Evidence: Countries: South Africa; Timeline: March 5th (day one) with lockdown initiated on day 21 and ending on 30 April 2020

Study: Mathematical modeling of COVID-19 containment strategies with considerations for limited medical resources
Factors: social distancing, where members of the population systematically reduce their interactions with other to limit the transmission rate of the virus
Excerpt: the Distancing-SEIRD model predicted the total number on deaths over a six month period with no social distancing to be as high as 130,000 people;  the most strict case of social distancing, with 80% adherence, led to a drastic reduction in the death toll - to under 1000 total deaths over the first six months
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Canada cities: Ontario; Timeline: Jan 25th, 2020 with social distancing beginning on March 17th

Study: Estimating the impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions on documented infections with COVID-19: A cross-country analysis
Factors: prohibition of small gatherings in public or private places
Excerpt: gathering bans (34 %; 95% CI 21-45 %) reduction in the number of new cases
Measure of Evidence: Countries: United States, Canada, Australia, the EU-15 countries, Norway, and Switzerland; Timeline:  April 15, 2020

Study: Mathematical assessment of the impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions on curtailing the 2019 novel Coronavirus
Factors: strict social distancing
Excerpt: The worst-case scenario projections for cumulative mortality (based on the baseline levels of anti-COVID non-pharmaceutical interventions considered in the study) decrease dramatically by 80% and 64%, respectively, if the strict social-distancing measures implemented are maintained until the end of May or June, 2020.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: United States; City: New York

Study: The December 2019 New Corona Virus (SARS-CoV-2) Outbreak: A Behavioral Infectious Disease Policy Model
Factors: social contact reduction measures
Excerpt: Figure 8 further highlights the strong interaction effect between behavioral responses to the outbreak. Figure 7 (left) shows the joint effect of social distancing and the threshold for building testing capacity. While a moderate higher/lower response has the effect of reducing (lighter colors)/increasing (darker colors) actual cumulative cases, their joint change strongly amplifies these effects. For example, policies that stimulate social distancing are greatly enhanced when policy makers and citizen have a more accurate perception of the extent of the outbreak.
Measure of Evidence: Regions: Asian, Europe, Africa, North America, South America, Oceania

Excerpt: We therefore explored the effects of additional social distancing measures that reduced input reproduction numbers of 25 and 33% on ICU requirements in relation to these same clinical care capacity constraints (Figure 4).

Study: The SARS-CoV-2 epidemic outbreak: a review of plausible scenarios of containment and mitigation for Mexico
Factors: physical isolation, avoidance of public gatherings
Excerpt: Figure 14 shows the case when 99% of population is isolated. We can see that the peak incidence occurs 2 days after isolation began (January 26th) indicating that the isolation process promotes an earlier decrease in incidence. This scenario underlines the importance of taking contingency measures with due anticipation, otherwise the number of cases will notoriously increase
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Mexico; Timeline: February 28, 2020 to March 26, 2020
